etymology.description: 辰(辰) (chén, "early form of dragon") as phonetic + stylized depiction of a dragon body = 龙 -> dragon
etymology.interpretation: 龙(龍) (lóng, "dragon") combines a phonetic element from 辰(辰) (chén, "early form of dragon") with a stylized representation of a dragon's body, capturing both sound and essence to represent the mythical creature.
etymology.simplification: 龙(龍) simplified by combining phonetic 辰(辰) with a less detailed body form to represent the dragon.

examples.chinese: 传说中的龙能呼风唤雨(傳說中的龍能呼風喚雨)。
examples.pinyin: Chuánshuō zhōng de lóng néng hū fēng huàn yǔ.
examples.english: The legendary dragon can summon wind and rain.

examples.chinese: 皇宫中悬挂着龙袍(皇宮中懸掛著龍袍)，象征着至高无上的权力(象徵著至高無上的權力)。
examples.pinyin: Huánggōng zhōng xuánguà zhe lóng páo, xiàngzhēng zhe zhìgāo wúshàng de quánlì.
examples.english: In the imperial palace, the dragon robe hangs, symbolizing supreme power.
